<record xmlns="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"><header><identifier>oai:ojs2.173.212.231.62:article/1</identifier><datestamp>2020-05-06T21:17:37Z</datestamp><setSpec>ijms:Edt</setSpec><setSpec>driver</setSpec></header><metadata><oai_dc:dc xmlns:oai_dc="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/" xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/  http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc.xsd"><dc:title xml:lang="en-US">Medical Simulation: Utilize, Inspire, Embrace , Verify</dc:title><dc:creator>McKenzie , Frederic </dc:creator><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Medical simulation</dc:subject><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Modeling, Simulation and Visualization Engineering</dc:subject><dc:description xml:lang="en-US">(Extract)I too have experienced the enthusiasm of an individual seeking to learn a new task. More years ago than I care to elaborate and before the proliferation of health care simulators, I visited the ER with a painful ache and had an interesting training experience with a youthful ER nurse. She looked around possibly to see if anyone could help or oversee her and noting that everyone else was busy and my veins were attractively prominent, she promptly asked if I would mind if she practiced drawing blood. Under duress due to pain perhaps, I agreed. I am not sure if the art and science of phlebotomy includes the part of chasing the vein with the needle under the epidermis or whether it is at the 3rd or 4th stick that phlebotomy starts to become something akin to torture but thankfully after the 4th stick, I received an apology and a surrender from the novice nurse and we waited for a more experienced practitioner.&amp;nbsp; That day I wished for a better way and hoped that no one else would need to endure the painful or even perilous results of such inexperience....&amp;nbsp;</dc:description><dc:publisher xml:lang="en-US">Mediterranean Journals</dc:publisher><dc:date>2014-05-10</dc:date><dc:type>info:eu-repo/semantics/article</dc:type><dc:type>info:eu-repo/semantics/publishedVersion</dc:type><dc:format>application/pdf</dc:format><dc:identifier>https://www.mbmj.org/index.php/ijms/article/view/1</dc:identifier><dc:identifier>10.15342/ijms.v1i1.5</dc:identifier><dc:source xml:lang="en-US">Integrative Journal of Medical Sciences; Therefore, extensive efforts have been performed on the science of medicine, and glorious advances have been gained especially in the last two centuries. Research is essential for medicine to develop new therapeutic methods and to monitor the results of the current treatment given to the patient. These are possibly the simplest reasons for investigations in medicine. On the other hand, qualified human resource, research ethics, financial supports, regular data recording and analysis, and publication are important issues for improvement of the medical researches in the developing countries....&amp;nbsp;</dc:description><dc:publisher xml:lang="en-US">Mediterranean Journals</dc:publisher><dc:date>2014-06-20</dc:date><dc:type>info:eu-repo/semantics/article</dc:type><dc:type>info:eu-repo/semantics/publishedVersion</dc:type><dc:format>application/pdf</dc:format><dc:identifier>https://www.mbmj.org/index.php/ijms/article/view/3</dc:identifier><dc:identifier>10.15342/ijms.v1i1.12</dc:identifier><dc:source xml:lang="en-US">Integrative Journal of Medical Sciences; Vol. 1 No. 1 (2014); 1-2</dc:source><dc:source>2658-8218</dc:source><dc:language>eng</dc:language><dc:relation>https://www.mbmj.org/index.php/ijms/article/view/3/324</dc:relation><dc:rights xml:lang="en-US">Copyright (c) 2014 Yusuf Yakupogullari and Adam KOSE</dc:rights><dc:rights xml:lang="en-US">https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/</dc:rights></oai_dc:dc></metadata></record><record xmlns="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"><header><identifier>oai:ojs2.173.212.231.62:article/4</identifier><datestamp>2020-05-06T21:17:04Z</datestamp><setSpec>ijms:ART</setSpec><setSpec>driver</setSpec></header><metadata><oai_dc:dc xmlns:oai_dc="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/" xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/  http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc.xsd"><dc:title xml:lang="en-US">Ocular Manifestations of Behcet's Disease: An Analysis of 133 Moroccan Patients</dc:title><dc:creator>Alami, Fadoua</dc:creator><dc:creator>El Berdaoui, Nadia</dc:creator><dc:creator>Imdary, Imane </dc:creator><dc:creator>Benchekroun, Nabiha</dc:creator><dc:creator>Hajji, Zakia</dc:creator><dc:creator>Berraho, Amina</dc:creator><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Behcet’s disease</dc:subject><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Uveitis</dc:subject><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Vasculitis</dc:subject><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Treatment</dc:subject><dc:description xml:lang="en-US">Introduction: Behcet’s disease is a systemic disorder linked to occlusive vasculitis and of a relatively unknown pathogenesis. Ocular manifestations of the disease mainly comprise uveitis in 60-80% of cases, followed by retinal vasculitis and then retinal vein occlusion. The aim of this study is to analyze ocular manifestations of patients with confirmed Behcet’s disease, their complications, treatment and evolution in our tertiary care unit of Morocco.&amp;nbsp;Patients and methods&amp;nbsp;:&amp;nbsp; It is a retrospective study of patients with confirmed Behcet along with ocular manifestations, hospitalized in the department&amp;nbsp;of&amp;nbsp;ophthalmology at the teaching hospital of Rabat from Juin 2002 to June 2012.Results: A total of 133 patients were included in the study, being 29,5 years-old on average. Visual acuity is very low before treatment: 56% had less than 1/10. Ocular manifestations included mainly uveitis with 89.96%, followed by retinal vasculitis 73.6% and maculopathy 22%. The percentage of the eyes of which the VA was inferior to 1/10 became 35.9% after the treatment.Conclusion: The most frequent clinical presentation in our context is a total uveitis with a posterior predominance associated with a vasculitis. Pupillary seclusion is the most frequent complication. Corticotherapy and immunosuppressive drugs are the therapeutic methods used the most in our context.</dc:description><dc:publisher xml:lang="en-US">Mediterranean Journals</dc:publisher><dc:date>2014-06-20</dc:date><dc:type>info:eu-repo/semantics/article</dc:type><dc:type>info:eu-repo/semantics/publishedVersion</dc:type><dc:format>application/pdf</dc:format><dc:identifier>https://www.mbmj.org/index.php/ijms/article/view/4</dc:identifier><dc:identifier>10.15342/ijms.v1i1.9</dc:identifier><dc:source xml:lang="en-US">Integrative Journal of Medical Sciences; Vol. 1 No. 1 (2014); 7-11</dc:source><dc:source>2658-8218</dc:source><dc:language>eng</dc:language><dc:relation>https://www.mbmj.org/index.php/ijms/article/view/4/327</dc:relation><dc:rights xml:lang="en-US">Copyright (c) 2014 Alami Fadoua et al.</dc:rights><dc:rights xml:lang="en-US">https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/</dc:rights></oai_dc:dc></metadata></record><record xmlns="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"><header><identifier>oai:ojs2.173.212.231.62:article/5</identifier><datestamp>2020-05-06T21:17:04Z</datestamp><setSpec>ijms:ART</setSpec><setSpec>driver</setSpec></header><metadata><oai_dc:dc xmlns:oai_dc="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/" xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/  http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc.xsd"><dc:title xml:lang="en-US">Silent Sinus Syndrome: A Retrospective Review of 11 Cases</dc:title><dc:creator>Darghal, Karima</dc:creator><dc:creator>Borki, Rajae</dc:creator><dc:creator>Essakalli, Leila</dc:creator><dc:creator>Lecanu, Jean-Baptiste</dc:creator><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Silent-Sinus-Syndrome</dc:subject><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Imaging</dc:subject><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Endoscopic Surgery</dc:subject><dc:description xml:lang="en-US">Objective:&amp;nbsp;The purpose of this study is to describe the clinical and radiological features of SSS, and to review therapeutic possibilities and their outcomes.Patients and Methods:&amp;nbsp;Retrospective observational case series in the department of Arthur Vernes Institute between Mars 2007 and&amp;nbsp; Novembre 2012. Clinical records, including ophthalmology and otolaryngology evaluations as well as computed tomography scans and operative reports, were carefully examined. A literature review for relevant studies was performed to examine similar cases.Results:&amp;nbsp;Eleven cases of &amp;nbsp;SSS were identified. Nine men and two women (sex ratio 4.5), aged between 23 and 54 years (mean, 30 years). there was 3 to 4 mm enophthalmos in 10 cases (90.9%), and hypoglobus in all cases, with no effect on visual function. In all 11 cases, the maxillary roof (orbital floor) was drawn downwards, and the one or more walls of the maxilla were concave. In 4 cases septal deviation was present. 8 patients (72.7%) underwent endoscopic sinus surgery, while 3 refused it. Septoplasty was performed in 4 cases (36.3%).Conclusion: The silent sinus syndrome is a rare entity. It mainly presents as unilateral enophthalmos in younger people and has very characteristic clinical and radiologic signs.This case series reports our diagnostic and therapeutic experience with this syndrome.</dc:description><dc:publisher xml:lang="en-US">Mediterranean Journals</dc:publisher><dc:date>2014-06-20</dc:date><dc:type>info:eu-repo/semantics/article</dc:type><dc:type>info:eu-repo/semantics/publishedVersion</dc:type><dc:format>application/pdf</dc:format><dc:identifier>https://www.mbmj.org/index.php/ijms/article/view/5</dc:identifier><dc:identifier>10.15342/ijms.v1i1.7</dc:identifier><dc:source xml:lang="en-US">Integrative Journal of Medical Sciences; Vol. 1 No. 1 (2014); 12-16</dc:source><dc:source>2658-8218</dc:source><dc:language>eng</dc:language><dc:relation>https://www.mbmj.org/index.php/ijms/article/view/5/328</dc:relation><dc:rights xml:lang="en-US">Copyright (c) 2014 Karima Darghal et al.</dc:rights><dc:rights xml:lang="en-US">https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/</dc:rights></oai_dc:dc></metadata></record><record xmlns="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"><header><identifier>oai:ojs2.173.212.231.62:article/6</identifier><datestamp>2020-06-27T19:19:17Z</datestamp><setSpec>ijms:ART</setSpec><setSpec>driver</setSpec></header><metadata><oai_dc:dc xmlns:oai_dc="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/" xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/  http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc.xsd"><dc:title xml:lang="en-US">Pediatric Tuberculosis at Moulay Youssef University Hopsital – Morocco</dc:title><dc:creator>Aharmim, Mohamed</dc:creator><dc:creator>Bouti, Khalid</dc:creator><dc:creator>Soualhi, Mouna</dc:creator><dc:creator>Hanim, Fatima Zohra</dc:creator><dc:creator>Marc, Karima</dc:creator><dc:creator>Zahraoui, Rachida</dc:creator><dc:creator>Benamor, Jouda</dc:creator><dc:creator>Bourkadi, Jamal Eddine</dc:creator><dc:creator>Iraqi, Ghali</dc:creator><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Pediatric</dc:subject><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Tuberculosis</dc:subject><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Pulmonary</dc:subject><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Lymph nodes</dc:subject><dc:description xml:lang="en-US">Background: There are few studies on presentations, treatment and outcomes of pediatric tuberculosis in Morocco. This study aimed to describe clinico-epidemiological profiles, laboratory findings, treatment and outcomes of pediatric tuberculosis (TB) in a tertiary care hospital in Morocco.Materials and Methods: This is a prospective, descriptive study undertaken in children diagnosed with TB between June 2011 and May 2012. Clinico-pidemiologicalprofiles, laboratory findings, treatment and outcome of patients was recorded. Statistical significance of category variables was evaluated. Analysis was done on SPSS package. Results were expressed as rates and proportions. Chi square test was used to test for statistical significance.&amp;nbsp;Results: 53 children aged 2 to 16 years (mean age of 9±3.2) with TB diagnosis were enrolled in our study. 33 (62%) of patients were female. Common symptoms were fever, cough, chest pain, dyspnea, decreased appetite and weight loss. The types of TB were: pulmonary TB (32, 60%), and extrapulmonary TB (21, 39.6%). The sites of pediatric extrapulmonary tuberculosis (EPTB) were: lymph nodes (7, 13.2%), peritoneal (6, 11.3%), meningeal (4, 7.5%) and osteoarticular (4, 7.5%). 24 (45,3%) of the patients had positive Calmette-Guérin vaccine scar, and 42(79.2%) of the patients had a positive tuberculin skin test. An adult TB contact was identified in 19 (35.8%) of the cases. On direct microscopy, acid-fast bacilli were found in 3 (5.6%) patients and positive cul¬ture for Mycobacterium tuberculosis was found in 2 (3.7%). Drug mono- or multiresistance was not detected.Conclusion: Paediatric TB in both pulmonary and extrapulmonary forms is a challenging diagnosis, and is a common occurrence in our setting. Diagnosis was based on a combination of epidemiological and clinical suspicion supported by results of various investigations.</dc:description><dc:publisher xml:lang="en-US">Mediterranean Journals</dc:publisher><dc:date>2020-06-20</dc:date><dc:type>info:eu-repo/semantics/article</dc:type><dc:type>info:eu-repo/semantics/publishedVersion</dc:type><dc:format>application/pdf</dc:format><dc:identifier>https://www.mbmj.org/index.php/ijms/article/view/6</dc:identifier><dc:identifier>10.15342/ijms.v1i1.4</dc:identifier><dc:source xml:lang="en-US">Integrative Journal of Medical Sciences; Vol. 1 No. 1 (2014); 17-22</dc:source><dc:source>2658-8218</dc:source><dc:language>eng</dc:language><dc:relation>https://www.mbmj.org/index.php/ijms/article/view/6/329</dc:relation><dc:rights xml:lang="en-US">Copyright (c) 2014 Mohamed Aharmim et al.</dc:rights><dc:rights xml:lang="en-US">https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/</dc:rights></oai_dc:dc></metadata></record><record xmlns="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"><header><identifier>oai:ojs2.173.212.231.62:article/7</identifier><datestamp>2020-05-06T21:17:04Z</datestamp><setSpec>ijms:CR</setSpec><setSpec>driver</setSpec></header><metadata><oai_dc:dc xmlns:oai_dc="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/" xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/  http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc.xsd"><dc:title xml:lang="en-US">Gastric Schwannoma: A Postoperative Surprise - A Case Report</dc:title><dc:creator>Ait Ali, Abdelmounaim</dc:creator><dc:creator>Essarghini, Mohamed</dc:creator><dc:creator>Hajjouji, Abderzak</dc:creator><dc:creator>Sair, Khalid</dc:creator><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Gastric schwannoma</dc:subject><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Submucosal tumor</dc:subject><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Partial gastrectomy</dc:subject><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">S-100 protein</dc:subject><dc:description xml:lang="en-US">Gastric Schwannoma is a rare, slow-growing, and clinically non-specific submucosal tumor, originating from Schwann cells with excellent prognosis after surgical resection.We report a clinical case of a patient presented with gastric schwannoma revealed by non-specific gastric signs and of which the definitive diagnosis is done through immunohistochemistry of the resected specimen, showing strong S100 protein positivity. The evolution is favorable after a partial gastrectomy with a decline of two years. Through this case, we are trying to trace the rarity, strong similarities with gastric stromal tumors and especially, the weak index of suspicion for this diagnosis.</dc:description><dc:publisher xml:lang="en-US">Mediterranean Journals</dc:publisher><dc:date>2014-06-20</dc:date><dc:type>info:eu-repo/semantics/article</dc:type><dc:type>info:eu-repo/semantics/publishedVersion</dc:type><dc:format>application/pdf</dc:format><dc:identifier>https://www.mbmj.org/index.php/ijms/article/view/7</dc:identifier><dc:identifier>10.15342/ijms.v1i1.3</dc:identifier><dc:source xml:lang="en-US">Integrative Journal of Medical Sciences; Vol. 1 No. 1 (2014); 23-25</dc:source><dc:source>2658-8218</dc:source><dc:language>eng</dc:language><dc:relation>https://www.mbmj.org/index.php/ijms/article/view/7/330</dc:relation><dc:rights xml:lang="en-US">Copyright (c) 2014 Abdelmounaim Ait Ali et al.</dc:rights><dc:rights xml:lang="en-US">https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/</dc:rights></oai_dc:dc></metadata></record><record xmlns="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"><header><identifier>oai:ojs2.173.212.231.62:article/8</identifier><datestamp>2020-05-06T21:17:04Z</datestamp><setSpec>ijms:CR</setSpec><setSpec>driver</setSpec></header><metadata><oai_dc:dc xmlns:oai_dc="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/" xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/  http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc.xsd"><dc:title xml:lang="en-US">Pedunculated Hepatic Hemangioma - A case report</dc:title><dc:creator>Elhajjam, Mostafa</dc:creator><dc:creator>Lahkim, Mohamed</dc:creator><dc:creator>Karji Al-Marzouqi, Mohamed</dc:creator><dc:creator>Lacombe, Pascal</dc:creator><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Pedunculated</dc:subject><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Hepatic</dc:subject><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Hemangioma</dc:subject><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Imaging</dc:subject><dc:description xml:lang="en-US">Pedunculated hemangioma is a rare and atypical hepatic angioma. We report the case of a pedunculated hepatic hemangioma presenting as an abdominal sub-hepatic mass incidentally discovered in a 66-year-old woman with anal cancer. The diagnosis was strongly suggested by the vascular features of the lesion on spiral computed tomography (CT) and magnetic resonance (MR) imaging. A surgical removal of the mass was decided to prevent potential risk of ischemic volvulus along the pedicle. Histo-pathological examination confirmed this diagnosis. Contrast enhanced thin sections and subsequent multiplanar reconstructions on CT and MR are very helpful to show the angioma features and the pedicle linking the lesion with the liver.</dc:description><dc:publisher xml:lang="en-US">Mediterranean Journals</dc:publisher><dc:date>2014-06-20</dc:date><dc:type>info:eu-repo/semantics/article</dc:type><dc:type>info:eu-repo/semantics/publishedVersion</dc:type><dc:format>application/pdf</dc:format><dc:identifier>https://www.mbmj.org/index.php/ijms/article/view/8</dc:identifier><dc:identifier>10.15342/ijms.v1i1.11</dc:identifier><dc:source xml:lang="en-US">Integrative Journal of Medical Sciences; Vol. 1 No. 1 (2014); 26-28</dc:source><dc:source>2658-8218</dc:source><dc:language>eng</dc:language><dc:relation>https://www.mbmj.org/index.php/ijms/article/view/8/331</dc:relation><dc:rights xml:lang="en-US">Copyright (c) 2014 Mostafa Elhajjam</dc:rights><dc:rights xml:lang="en-US">https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/</dc:rights></oai_dc:dc></metadata></record><record xmlns="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"><header><identifier>oai:ojs2.173.212.231.62:article/9</identifier><datestamp>2020-05-06T21:17:03Z</datestamp><setSpec>ijms:Edt</setSpec><setSpec>driver</setSpec></header><metadata><oai_dc:dc xmlns:oai_dc="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/" xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/  http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc.xsd"><dc:title xml:lang="en-US">English as a Lingua Franca of Science in Morocco</dc:title><dc:creator>Bouti, Khalid</dc:creator><dc:creator>Borki, Rajae</dc:creator><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">English</dc:subject><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Lingua franca</dc:subject><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Morocco</dc:subject><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Science</dc:subject><dc:description xml:lang="en-US">EXTRACT: During the Golden Age of Arabic-Islamic science (8th to 13th centuries C.E.), and due to the Islamic extension in the world, where a large part of the earth, from southern Europe throughout North Africa to Central Asia and on to India, was controlled by and/or influenced by the new Arabic-Muslim Empire, the Arabic science translations from Greek, Latin, and Chinese into Arabic were necessary, which made Arabic as the only language of science in Africa, Asia, and Europe during that age. Between the 15th and 17th centuries, Latin took this strategic role, ...</dc:description><dc:publisher xml:lang="en-US">Mediterranean Journals</dc:publisher><dc:date>2014-12-21</dc:date><dc:type>info:eu-repo/semantics/article</dc:type><dc:type>info:eu-repo/semantics/publishedVersion</dc:type><dc:format>application/pdf</dc:format><dc:identifier>https://www.mbmj.org/index.php/ijms/article/view/9</dc:identifier><dc:identifier>10.15342/ijms.v1i2.58</dc:identifier><dc:source xml:lang="en-US">Integrative Journal of Medical Sciences; Vol. 1 No. 2 (2014); 29-30</dc:source><dc:source>2658-8218</dc:source><dc:language>eng</dc:language><dc:relation>https://www.mbmj.org/index.php/ijms/article/view/9/332</dc:relation><dc:rights xml:lang="en-US">Copyright (c) 2014 Khalid Bouti and Rajae Borki</dc:rights><dc:rights xml:lang="en-US">https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/</dc:rights></oai_dc:dc></metadata></record><record xmlns="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"><header><identifier>oai:ojs2.173.212.231.62:article/10</identifier><datestamp>2020-05-06T21:17:04Z</datestamp><setSpec>ijms:MA</setSpec><setSpec>driver</setSpec></header><metadata><oai_dc:dc xmlns:oai_dc="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/" xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/  http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc.xsd"><dc:title xml:lang="en-US">Cannabis Smoking and Risk of Lung Cancer - A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis</dc:title><dc:creator>Bouti, Khalid</dc:creator><dc:creator>Borki, Rajae</dc:creator><dc:creator>Fenane, Hicham</dc:creator><dc:creator>Harrak, Laila</dc:creator><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Cannabis Smoking</dc:subject><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Risk Of Lung Cancer</dc:subject><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Systematic Review</dc:subject><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Meta-Analysis</dc:subject><dc:description xml:lang="en-US">Background:&amp;nbsp;Cannabis is the illicit psychoactive substance the most consumed in the world. Little is known about the association between the use of cannabis and the risk of lung cancer.Objective:The objective of this meta-analysis is to determine whether use of cannabis is a risk factor for lung cancer.Methods:&amp;nbsp;We conducted a systematic review and meta-analyses of all languages articles using relevant computerised databases. MEDLINE (online PubMed), Web of knowledge, Embase, EBSCO CINAHL, ScienceDirect, Scopus, Cochrane Library, and Directory of Open Access Journals were searched to September 2014 for cohorts and case-control studies that assessed the risk of lung cancer associated with cannabis smoking.&amp;nbsp; The literature search was performed with a combination of medical subject headings terms, "cannabis" and "lung neoplasms". Data extraction: Two investigators independently analysed and extracted results from eligible studies. Our study's registration number on PROSPERO is&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;CRD42014008872.Results:&amp;nbsp;The search strategy identified 2476 citations. 13 studies were eligible for inclusion: 2 pooled analysis of 9 case-control studies, one case-control study and 3 cohorts.The cumulative analysis for all the studies under a fixed-effects model showed that cannabis smoking determined an increased risk of developing lung cancer in the future (relative risk 1.22, 95% confidence interval 0.999–1.5; p=0.051), with no evidence of heterogeneity across the studies (I2: 34%; p¼0.01).Conclusions:&amp;nbsp;The use of cannabis with or without tobacco smoking is associated with an increased risk for lung cancer.</dc:description><dc:publisher xml:lang="en-US">Mediterranean Journals</dc:publisher><dc:date>2014-05-14</dc:date><dc:type>info:eu-repo/semantics/article</dc:type><dc:type>info:eu-repo/semantics/publishedVersion</dc:type><dc:format>text/html</dc:format><dc:format>application/pdf</dc:format><dc:identifier>https://www.mbmj.org/index.php/ijms/article/view/10</dc:identifier><dc:identifier>10.15342/ijms.v1i2.57</dc:identifier><dc:source 31-37</dc:source><dc:source>2658-8218</dc:source><dc:language>eng</dc:language><dc:relation>https://www.mbmj.org/index.php/ijms/article/view/10/146</dc:relation><dc:relation>https://www.mbmj.org/index.php/ijms/article/view/10/333</dc:relation><dc:rights xmlns:oai_dc="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/" xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/  http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc.xsd"><dc:title xml:lang="en-US">Topical negative pressure therapy Recent experience of the department of plastic surgery at Ibn Sina University Hospital, Rabat, Morocco</dc:title><dc:creator>Echchaoui, Abdelmoughit</dc:creator><dc:creator>Benyachou, Malika</dc:creator><dc:creator>Hafidi, Jawad</dc:creator><dc:creator>Elaissaoui, Imane</dc:creator><dc:creator>Zaouri, Hasna</dc:creator><dc:creator>Elmazouz, Samir</dc:creator><dc:creator>Gharib, Noureddine</dc:creator><dc:creator>Abbassi, Abdellah</dc:creator><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Loss of substance</dc:subject><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Negative pressure</dc:subject><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Budding</dc:subject><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Healing</dc:subject><dc:description xml:lang="en-US">Introduction :&amp;nbsp;The topical negative pressure therapy (TNP) is a non-invasive method to treat chronic and acute wounds locally, using a continuous or intermittent negative pressure.&amp;nbsp;The objective of this study is to present the first experience of this type of treatment used in clinical cases in our department. By presenting these cases, we highlight indication and efficiency of this new technique applied in relatively complicated situations, at the same time it also allows a significant improvement in treating injuries and chronic wounds.Materials and methods :&amp;nbsp;In this study, we present the recent experience of the Department of Reconstructive and Plastic Surgery of the University Hospital Center of Avicenne in Rabat. This therapy was used for the first time this year (in 2014), in three young patients who presented with chronic wounds associated with local and general factors that are unfavorable for the healing process.Results :&amp;nbsp;In all three of our cases we obtained highly satisfactory clinical results.&amp;nbsp;TNP allows wounds to bud in a shorter time, as well as a fast healing by second intention due to controlled wound healing or split-skin graft without using flaps. This enables to decrease the margin of error, the time and the number of dressing replacements, and to reduce the length of hospital stay.Conclusion :&amp;nbsp;This is an expensive and specific equipment. However, the cost-benefit ratio analysis shows that it is an essential method that should be part of our therapeutic strategies.</dc:description><dc:publisher xml:lang="en-US">Mediterranean Journals</dc:publisher><dc:date>2014-12-21</dc:date><dc:type>info:eu-repo/semantics/article</dc:type><dc:type>info:eu-repo/semantics/publishedVersion</dc:type><dc:format>application/pdf</dc:format><dc:identifier>https://www.mbmj.org/index.php/ijms/article/view/11</dc:identifier><dc:identifier>10.15342/ijms.v1i2.42</dc:identifier><dc:source xml:lang="en-US">Integrative Journal of Medical Sciences; Vol. 1 No. 2 (2014); 38-43</dc:source><dc:source>2658-8218</dc:source><dc:language>eng</dc:language><dc:relation>https://www.mbmj.org/index.php/ijms/article/view/11/334</dc:relation><dc:rights xml:lang="en-US">Copyright (c) 2014 Abdelmoughit Echchaoui et al.</dc:rights><dc:rights xml:lang="en-US">https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/</dc:rights></oai_dc:dc></metadata></record><record xmlns="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"><header><identifier>oai:ojs2.173.212.231.62:article/12</identifier><datestamp>2020-05-06T21:17:03Z</datestamp><setSpec>ijms:ART</setSpec><setSpec>driver</setSpec></header><metadata><oai_dc:dc xmlns:oai_dc="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/" xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/  http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc.xsd"><dc:title xml:lang="en-US">Malignant orbital tumors in children: A series of 4 cases</dc:title><dc:creator>Alami, Fadoua</dc:creator><dc:creator>Imdary, Imane</dc:creator><dc:creator>El Hassan, Abdellah</dc:creator><dc:creator>Chefchaouini, Moulay Cherif</dc:creator><dc:creator>Berraho, Amina</dc:creator><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Pediatric</dc:subject><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Malignant</dc:subject><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Tumor</dc:subject><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Orbit</dc:subject><dc:description xml:lang="en-US">
Introduction: Malignant tumors in children are rare but serious conditions as they can impair function and survival. Tumors in pediatric patients can originate from the orbit. Rarely, the tumor spreads to the adjacent areas and occasionally it may metastasize.Objectives:&amp;nbsp;The objective of this study is to present the common symptoms and the clinical and radiological characteristics of most common malignant orbital tumors in children.Materials and methods: Through the discussion of 4 clinical cases of children presenting with exophthalmos due to a tumor, the authors highlight that clinical symptoms are usually less specific, and that imaging has an important role in diagnosis, determining location, and local and regional expansion of the tumor in order to find the adequate therapy.Results: Our patients' ages ranged from 2 to 5 years. The revealing sign in each case was a unilateral exophthalmos due to a tumor, which could only be reduced minimally or not at all. Its evolution has been rapidly progressive. Orbital imaging and histologic study, if biopsy was possible, allowed guiding the positive diagnosis of the malignant nature and its local and regional spreading, as well as the adequate treatment.Conclusion: Orbital tumors are rare in the pediatric population. However, due to recent remarkable progress obtained through both complimentary diagnostic tools and treatments, these malignancies deserve the attention of both the ophthalmologists and the pediatricians.
</dc:description><dc:publisher xml:lang="en-US">Mediterranean Journals</dc:publisher><dc:date>2014-12-21</dc:date><dc:type>info:eu-repo/semantics/article</dc:type><dc:type>info:eu-repo/semantics/publishedVersion</dc:type><dc:format>application/pdf</dc:format><dc:identifier>https://www.mbmj.org/index.php/ijms/article/view/12</dc:identifier><dc:identifier>10.15342/ijms.v1i2.6</dc:identifier><dc:source xml:lang="en-US">Integrative Journal of Medical Sciences; Vol. 1 No. 2 (2014); 44-48</dc:source><dc:source>2658-8218</dc:source><dc:language>eng</dc:language><dc:relation>https://www.mbmj.org/index.php/ijms/article/view/12/336</dc:relation><dc:rights xml:lang="en-US">Copyright (c) 2014 Fadoua Alami et al.</dc:rights><dc:rights xml:lang="en-US">https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/</dc:rights></oai_dc:dc></metadata></record><record xmlns="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"><header><identifier>oai:ojs2.173.212.231.62:article/13</identifier><datestamp>2020-05-06T21:17:03Z</datestamp><setSpec>ijms:ART</setSpec><setSpec>driver</setSpec></header><metadata><oai_dc:dc xmlns:oai_dc="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/" xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/  http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc.xsd"><dc:title xml:lang="en-US">Lymph Node Involvement In Upper Aerodigestive Tract Cancers - A Clinical Study at Specialities University Hospital of Rabat</dc:title><dc:creator>Borki, Rajae </dc:creator><dc:creator>Elayoubi, Ali</dc:creator><dc:creator>Bencheikh, Razika</dc:creator><dc:creator>Oujilal, Abdelilah</dc:creator><dc:creator>Benbouzid, Anass</dc:creator><dc:creator>Essakalli, Leila</dc:creator><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">UADT cancer</dc:subject><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Lymph node invasion</dc:subject><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Clinical</dc:subject><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Radiology</dc:subject><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Histology</dc:subject><dc:description xml:lang="en-US">Introduction: Cervical lymph node involvement has a major impact on prognosis and treatment decisions in patients with upper aerodigestive tract (UADT) cancer.&amp;nbsp;Objective: The aim of this study was to assess the incidence and pattern of cervical lymph node (LN) metastases in cancers of the upper aerodigestive tract.Methods:&amp;nbsp;This prospective study was conducted by the Department of ENT and Maxillofacial Surgery at Specialities University Hospital of Rabat, collecting data between October 2009 and December 2011. Lymph nodes were counted, clinically and radiologically localized, excised, then studied histologically.Results:&amp;nbsp;During this period, 106 patients have been treated surgically with a recent diagnosis of UADT cancer. The average age of our patients was 55±13.3 years, while male/female ratio was 3.5 to 1. More than half of our patients were operated with cancer of the larynx (58.5%, n=62); 27.4% (n=29) of patients suffered from oral cavity cancer and 14.2% (n=15) had cancer of the hypopharinx. Cervical lymph node invasion was estimated at 31.2% clinically, and 38.7% radiologically and histologically, distributed in different sites.Although the percentage of the invasion is almost similar clinically, radiologically and histologically, the high number of false positives and true negatives according to clinical and radiological exams confirms that specificity and sensitivity of these two exams is still poor compared to histology.Conclusion:&amp;nbsp;Thus, cervical metastases have to be diagnosed histologically. Moreover, the low percentage of lymph node invasions in the case of a UADT cancer suggests that the use of sentinel lymph node technique could be important, as it has been validated for small T1T2N0 tumors in the oral cavity. Further studies are needed to confirm its validity in case of other UADT tumor types.</dc:description><dc:publisher xml:lang="en-US">Mediterranean Journals</dc:publisher><dc:date>2014-12-21</dc:date><dc:type>info:eu-repo/semantics/article</dc:type><dc:type>info:eu-repo/semantics/publishedVersion</dc:type><dc:format>application/pdf</dc:format><dc:identifier>https://www.mbmj.org/index.php/ijms/article/view/13</dc:identifier><dc:identifier>10.15342/ijms.v1i2.56</dc:identifier><dc:source xml:lang="en-US">Integrative Journal of Medical Sciences; Vol. 1 No. 2 (2014); 49-52</dc:source><dc:source>2658-8218</dc:source><dc:language>eng</dc:language><dc:relation>https://www.mbmj.org/index.php/ijms/article/view/13/337</dc:relation><dc:rights xml:lang="en-US">Copyright (c) 2014 Rajae Borki et al.</dc:rights><dc:rights xml:lang="en-US">https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/</dc:rights></oai_dc:dc></metadata></record><record xmlns="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"><header><identifier>oai:ojs2.173.212.231.62:article/14</identifier><datestamp>2020-05-06T21:17:03Z</datestamp><setSpec>ijms:CR</setSpec><setSpec>driver</setSpec></header><metadata><oai_dc:dc xmlns:oai_dc="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/" xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/  http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc.xsd"><dc:title xml:lang="en-US">Non-Accidental Flecainide Overdose - A Case Report</dc:title><dc:creator>Ghannam, Abdelilah</dc:creator><dc:creator>Tazi, Abdellah</dc:creator><dc:creator>Kettani, Ali </dc:creator><dc:creator>Faroudy, Mamoun </dc:creator><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Drug intoxication</dc:subject><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Flecainide</dc:subject><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Cardiogenic shock</dc:subject><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Symptomatic treatment</dc:subject><dc:description xml:lang="en-US">Flecainide acetate is an antiarrhythmic drug used in the treatment of supraventricular arrhythmias. Flecainide causes very rare but often serious intoxications. These intoxications happen either due to a non-accidental overdose or because of a narrow therapeutic index in a patient who suffers from cardiomyopathy or has electrolyte abnormalities. We report an original case of a patient who had taken a high dose of flecainide with the aim of suicide. The patient suffered a cardiogenic shock with complications of lactic metabolic acidosis. Fast diagnosis is essential to reduce the high morbidity and mortality of this intoxication. The treatment plan is symptomatic. It aims at eliminating the poison and compensating cardiac function by treating the shock and the electrolyte imbalances. This allowed us to swiftly regain normal electrical and mechanical cardiac function in our patient. 3 weeks after the psychiatric consultation no sequelae were found. This case highlights that thorough history is essential in order to determine the diagnosis of a drug intoxication since the range of used products is wide. On the other hand, in case of any intoxication, while we apply a specific treatment, a well-managed, systematic, symptomatic treatment is essential to reduce morbidity and mortality.</dc:description><dc:publisher xml:lang="en-US">Mediterranean Journals</dc:publisher><dc:date>2014-12-21</dc:date><dc:type>info:eu-repo/semantics/article</dc:type><dc:type>info:eu-repo/semantics/publishedVersion</dc:type><dc:format>application/pdf</dc:format><dc:identifier>https://www.mbmj.org/index.php/ijms/article/view/14</dc:identifier><dc:identifier>10.15342/ijms.v1i2.18</dc:identifier><dc:source xml:lang="en-US">Integrative Journal of Medical Sciences; Vol. 1 No. 2 (2014); 53-55</dc:source><dc:source>2658-8218</dc:source><dc:language>eng</dc:language><dc:relation>https://www.mbmj.org/index.php/ijms/article/view/14/338</dc:relation><dc:rights xml:lang="en-US">Copyright (c) 2014 Abdelilah Ghannam et al.</dc:rights><dc:rights xml:lang="en-US">https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/</dc:rights></oai_dc:dc></metadata></record><record xmlns="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"><header><identifier>oai:ojs2.173.212.231.62:article/15</identifier><datestamp>2020-05-06T21:17:03Z</datestamp><setSpec>ijms:CR</setSpec><setSpec>driver</setSpec></header><metadata><oai_dc:dc xmlns:oai_dc="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/" xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/  http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc.xsd"><dc:title xml:lang="en-US">The False Equivalent of Terrible Triad of Elbow Combined with Neurovascular Damage in a Rugby Player - A New Case Report</dc:title><dc:creator>Boussakri, Hassan</dc:creator><dc:creator>Elibrahimi, Abdelhalim</dc:creator><dc:creator>Alassaf, Ihab</dc:creator><dc:creator>Bachiri, Mohammed</dc:creator><dc:creator>ELayoubi, Abdelghani</dc:creator><dc:creator>Elmrini, Abdelmajid</dc:creator><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Equivalent of terrible triad</dc:subject><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Anterior dislocation</dc:subject><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Elbow</dc:subject><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Neurovascular lesion</dc:subject><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Contact sport</dc:subject><dc:description xml:lang="en-US">Terrible triad is a severe traumatic injury of the elbow. We report a new variety of this clinical entity originating from a rare combination of injuries, namely the fracture-dislocation of the right elbow. The symptoms are acute ischemia of the hand with neurological damage following a sport accident suffered by a professional rugby player. We treated him surgically after immediate reduction of the dislocation. The short-term monitoring was clinical, while in the medium-term it was radiological and electrophysiological. On the whole, our (clinical, electrophysiological and radiological) results obtained initially, and medium-term during the last consultation, were satisfactory. The objective of this study is to draw attention to this clinical and radiological variety, as well as to its neurovascular complications and to discuss its therapeutic treatment. During the vascular and neurologic exam we should pay attention to and systematically look for neurovascular complications when treating a similar clinical case.</dc:description><dc:publisher xml:lang="en-US">Mediterranean Journals</dc:publisher><dc:date>2014-12-21</dc:date><dc:type>info:eu-repo/semantics/article</dc:type><dc:type>info:eu-repo/semantics/publishedVersion</dc:type><dc:format>application/pdf</dc:format><dc:identifier>https://www.mbmj.org/index.php/ijms/article/view/15</dc:identifier><dc:identifier>10.15342/ijms.v1i2.47</dc:identifier><dc:source xml:lang="en-US">Integrative Journal of Medical Sciences; Vol. 1 No. 2 (2014); 56-59</dc:source><dc:source>2658-8218</dc:source><dc:language>eng</dc:language><dc:relation>https://www.mbmj.org/index.php/ijms/article/view/15/339</dc:relation><dc:rights xml:lang="en-US">Copyright (c) 2014 Hassan Boussakri et al.</dc:rights><dc:rights xml:lang="en-US">https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/</dc:rights></oai_dc:dc></metadata></record><record xmlns="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"><header><identifier>oai:ojs2.173.212.231.62:article/16</identifier><datestamp>2020-05-06T21:17:03Z</datestamp><setSpec>ijms:Edt</setSpec><setSpec>driver</setSpec></header><metadata><oai_dc:dc xmlns:oai_dc="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/" xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/  http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc.xsd"><dc:title xml:lang="en-US">Public-Private Partnerships In Health</dc:title><dc:creator>Bouti, Khalid</dc:creator><dc:creator>Borki, Rajae</dc:creator><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Public-Private Partnership</dc:subject><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Health</dc:subject><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Morocco</dc:subject><dc:description xml:lang="en-US">Extract: The current importance of public debt requires governments to increasingly shift towards Public-Private Partnerships (PPPs). They are long-term contracts of private financing method providing or contributing to public service. The payment is made by the public partner and/or users of the service.The World Health Organization (WHO) defines this type of partnership as ‘‘a means to bring together a set of actors for the common goal of improving the health of populations based on mutually agreed roles and principles.’’Historically, the principle of PPP was established by the Private Finance Initiative (PFI), launched by the conservative government of John Major in 1992. It was from this moment that this model quickly spread to the rest of the world. In the mid-90s and from Australia, PPP agreement began to become part of the language of governments. In 1997, Labour with Tony Blair leading, strongly developed this management method, first and particularly in hospitals and then, in the entire public sector and spreading to the Royal Navy. Today, 10-15% of British public investments are made using PFI method.</dc:description><dc:publisher xml:lang="en-US">Mediterranean Journals</dc:publisher><dc:date>2015-06-30</dc:date><dc:type>info:eu-repo/semantics/article</dc:type><dc:type>info:eu-repo/semantics/publishedVersion</dc:type><dc:format>application/pdf</dc:format><dc:identifier>https://www.mbmj.org/index.php/ijms/article/view/16</dc:identifier><dc:identifier>10.15342/ijms.v2i1.66</dc:identifier><dc:source xml:lang="en-US">Integrative Journal of Medical Sciences; Vol. 2 No. 1 (2015); 1-2</dc:source><dc:source>2658-8218</dc:source><dc:language>eng</dc:language><dc:relation>https://www.mbmj.org/index.php/ijms/article/view/16/340</dc:relation><dc:rights xml:lang="en-US">Copyright (c) 2015 Khalid Bouti and Rajae Borki</dc:rights></oai_dc:dc></metadata></record><record xmlns="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"><header><identifier>oai:ojs2.173.212.231.62:article/17</identifier><datestamp>2020-05-06T21:17:03Z</datestamp><setSpec>ijms:ART</setSpec><setSpec>driver</setSpec></header><metadata><oai_dc:dc xmlns:oai_dc="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/" xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/  http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc.xsd"><dc:title xml:lang="en-US">Neurological Manifestations In Inflammatory Bowel Disease</dc:title><dc:creator>Hnach, Youssef</dc:creator><dc:creator>Ajana, Fatima Zahra</dc:creator><dc:creator>Benbelbaghdadi, Imane</dc:creator><dc:creator>Essamri, Wafaa</dc:creator><dc:creator>Afifi, Rajae</dc:creator><dc:creator>Benazzouz, Mustapha</dc:creator><dc:creator>Essaid Elfeydi, Abdellah</dc:creator><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Inflammatory bowel disease</dc:subject><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Ischemic stroke</dc:subject><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Peripheral neuropathies</dc:subject><dc:description xml:lang="en-US">Introduction :&amp;nbsp;The purpose of this retrospective study was to report neurological manifestations noted in patients who were monitored for inflammatory bowel disease, in order to document the pathophysiological, clinical, progressive, and therapeutic characteristics of this entity.Material and methods :&amp;nbsp;We conducted a retrospective study on patients monitored -in the gastroenterology service in Ibn Sina Hospital in Rabat, Morocco- for inflammatory bowel disease from 1992 till 2013 and who developed neurological manifestations during its course. Patients with iatrogenic complications were excluded, as well as patients with cerebrovascular risk factors.&amp;nbsp;Results :&amp;nbsp;There were 6 patients, 4 of whom have developed peripheral manifestations. Electromyography enabled the diagnosis to be made and the outcome was favorable with disappearance of clinical manifestations and normalization of the electromyography.&amp;nbsp;The other 2 patients, monitored for Crohn’s disease, developed ischemic stroke. Cerebral computed tomography angiography provided positive and topographic diagnosis. Two patients were admitted to specialized facilities.Conclusion :&amp;nbsp;Neurological manifestations in inflammatory bowel disease are rarely reported.&amp;nbsp; Peripheral neuropathies and stroke remain the most common manifestations. The mechanisms of these manifestations are not clearly defined yet. Currently, we hypothesize the interaction of immune mediators.</dc:description><dc:publisher xml:lang="en-US">Mediterranean Journals</dc:publisher><dc:date>2015-06-30</dc:date><dc:type>info:eu-repo/semantics/article</dc:type><dc:type>info:eu-repo/semantics/publishedVersion</dc:type><dc:format>application/pdf</dc:format><dc:identifier>https://www.mbmj.org/index.php/ijms/article/view/17</dc:identifier><dc:identifier>10.15342/ijms.v2i1.59</dc:identifier><dc:source xml:lang="en-US">Integrative Journal of Medical Sciences; Vol. 2 No. 1 (2015); 3-6</dc:source><dc:source>2658-8218</dc:source><dc:language>eng</dc:language><dc:relation>https://www.mbmj.org/index.php/ijms/article/view/17/341</dc:relation><dc:rights xml:lang="en-US">Copyright (c) 2015 Youssef Hnach et al.</dc:rights><dc:rights xml:lang="en-US">https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/</dc:rights></oai_dc:dc></metadata></record><record xmlns="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"><header><identifier>oai:ojs2.173.212.231.62:article/18</identifier><datestamp>2020-05-06T21:17:03Z</datestamp><setSpec>ijms:ART</setSpec><setSpec>driver</setSpec></header><metadata><oai_dc:dc xmlns:oai_dc="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/" xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/  http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc.xsd"><dc:title xml:lang="en-US">Head and Neck Sarcomas - Our Experience at a Tertiary Care Center in Rabat, Morocco</dc:title><dc:creator>Borki, Rajae</dc:creator><dc:creator>Nitassi, Sophia</dc:creator><dc:creator>El Ayoubi, Ali</dc:creator><dc:creator>Bencheikh, Razika</dc:creator><dc:creator>Oujilal, Abdelilah</dc:creator><dc:creator>Benbouzid, Anass</dc:creator><dc:creator>Essakalli, Leila</dc:creator><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Head and neck</dc:subject><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">ENT</dc:subject><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Sarcomas</dc:subject><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Cancers</dc:subject><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Surgery</dc:subject><dc:description xml:lang="en-US">Introduction: Head and neck sarcomas are rare, malignant and very heterogeneous tumors. The difficulty to manage these sarcomas requires the intervention of a multidisciplinary team to improve the prognosis. The aim of our study is to report our series (epidemiological, histological and progressive characteristics) and evaluate our treatment results.Patients and methods:&amp;nbsp;This is a retrospective study on 42 cases of head and neck sarcomas, assembled at ENT and Maxillofacial Surgery department in the University Hospital of Rabat, for a period of 5 years (2010-2015). All sarcomas were confirmed by histological examination with immunohistochemical study.Results:&amp;nbsp;There were 29 men and 13 women. The average age of our patients was 35.5 years (extremes of age: 13 and 70 years). All patients received a CT scan with MRI scan in 21 cases. A remote extension assessment showed lung metastases in 8 cases. The most frequently found histological type was synovial sarcoma, which was noted in 13 patients (30.9%) followed by osteosarcoma (21.2%). The osteosarcoma treatment was curative in 19 cases, based on surgery with radiotherapy. Total remission was noted in twelve patients.Conclusion:&amp;nbsp;Head and neck sarcomas are rare and very aggressive cancers with poor prognosis. The treatment approach combines surgery and chemoradiation. However, in the absence of adequate and effective treatment protocols, it is necessary to establish a surgical indication in time to ensure excision as complete as possible.</dc:description><dc:publisher xml:lang="en-US">Mediterranean Journals</dc:publisher><dc:date>2015-06-30</dc:date><dc:type>info:eu-repo/semantics/article</dc:type><dc:type>info:eu-repo/semantics/publishedVersion</dc:type><dc:format>application/pdf</dc:format><dc:identifier>https://www.mbmj.org/index.php/ijms/article/view/18</dc:identifier><dc:identifier>10.15342/ijms.v2i1.67</dc:identifier><dc:source xml:lang="en-US">Integrative Journal of Medical Sciences; Vol. 2 No. 1 (2015); 7-10</dc:source><dc:source>2658-8218</dc:source><dc:language>eng</dc:language><dc:relation>https://www.mbmj.org/index.php/ijms/article/view/18/342</dc:relation><dc:rights xml:lang="en-US">Copyright (c) 2015 Rajae Borki et al.</dc:rights><dc:rights xml:lang="en-US">https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/</dc:rights></oai_dc:dc></metadata></record><record xmlns="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"><header><identifier>oai:ojs2.173.212.231.62:article/19</identifier><datestamp>2020-05-06T21:17:03Z</datestamp><setSpec>ijms:ART</setSpec><setSpec>driver</setSpec></header><metadata><oai_dc:dc xmlns:oai_dc="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/" xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/  http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc.xsd"><dc:title xml:lang="en-US">Pulmonary Tuberculosis and Diabetes Mellitus Profile</dc:title><dc:creator>Kouismi, Hatim</dc:creator><dc:creator>Hammi, Sanae</dc:creator><dc:creator>Bouti, Khalid</dc:creator><dc:creator>Rhanim, Aziza</dc:creator><dc:creator>Ataouna, Khaoula</dc:creator><dc:creator>Razine, Rachid</dc:creator><dc:creator>Bourkadi, Jamal Eddine</dc:creator><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Tuberculosis</dc:subject><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Diabetes</dc:subject><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Risk factor</dc:subject><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Prevalence</dc:subject><dc:description xml:lang="en-US">Background :&amp;nbsp;About 95% of patients with tuberculosis (TB) and 70% of patients with diabetes mellitus (DM) live in low and middle-income countries. As a result, DM and TB are increasingly occurring together. The risk of tuberculosis is two to five times greater in patients with diabetes.The purpose of this study is to analyze the characteristics of pulmonary tuberculosis in patients with diabetes and to evaluate the impact of tuberculosis on diabetes control.Patients and Methods :&amp;nbsp;This is a retrospective study of 80 patients with confirmed pulmonary tuberculosis, comparing 30 patients with diabetes with 50 without diabetes.Results :&amp;nbsp;Diabetes was more frequent in older patients with tuberculosis and in male patients. 63,3% had type 2 diabetes. Tuberculosis symptoms did not differ between the two groups. Involvement of basal segments of the lower lobes and cavitation occurred more frequently in patients with diabetes, but this difference was not significant.&amp;nbsp;The time for conversion to negative of sputum culture was longer in control patients (44,1 ± 20,2 days) than in case (36 ± 18.3) (p = 0.08).Conclusion :&amp;nbsp;Tuberculosis is frequently associated with diabetes mainly in low-income countries. The problem with this association could be accentuated in the future.</dc:description><dc:publisher xml:lang="en-US">Mediterranean Journals</dc:publisher><dc:date>2015-06-30</dc:date><dc:type>info:eu-repo/semantics/article</dc:type><dc:type>info:eu-repo/semantics/publishedVersion</dc:type><dc:format>application/pdf</dc:format><dc:identifier>https://www.mbmj.org/index.php/ijms/article/view/19</dc:identifier><dc:identifier>10.15342/ijms.v2i1.68</dc:identifier><dc:source xml:lang="en-US">Integrative Journal of Medical Sciences; Vol. 2 No. 1 (2015); 11-15</dc:source><dc:source>2658-8218</dc:source><dc:language>eng</dc:language><dc:relation>https://www.mbmj.org/index.php/ijms/article/view/19/343</dc:relation><dc:rights xml:lang="en-US">Copyright (c) 2015 Hatim Kouismi et al.</dc:rights><dc:rights xml:lang="en-US">https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/</dc:rights></oai_dc:dc></metadata></record><record xmlns="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"><header><identifier>oai:ojs2.173.212.231.62:article/20</identifier><datestamp>2020-05-06T21:17:03Z</datestamp><setSpec>ijms:CR</setSpec><setSpec>driver</setSpec></header><metadata><oai_dc:dc xmlns:oai_dc="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/" xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/  http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc.xsd"><dc:title xml:lang="en-US">Holt-Oram syndrome: a simple diagnosis that is often delayed</dc:title><dc:creator>Bakkali, Abderrahmane</dc:creator><dc:creator>Harrag, Jamal Eddine</dc:creator><dc:creator>Koulekey, Dodji</dc:creator><dc:creator>Benlafqih, Chakib</dc:creator><dc:creator>Sayeh, Rochd</dc:creator><dc:creator>Laaroussi, Mohamed</dc:creator><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Holt–Oram syndrome</dc:subject><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Congenital heart disease</dc:subject><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Musculoskeletal abnormalities</dc:subject><dc:description xml:lang="en-US">Background: Holt-Oram syndrome is uncommon. It is characterized by heart disease and skeletal abnormalities of the hands and arms (upper limbs). This conditionis inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder. The most common problem is an atrial septal defect, and upper limb musculoskeletal deformities. These morphological characteristics should suggest a cardiac abnormality which is usually silent.Cases presentation: We report isolated cases with this syndrome. Tow patients with skeletal anomalies have been survived 11 and 29 years with their congenital cardiac defects without being diagnosed in despite of their obvious upper limbs deformities. In the two cases, the diagnosis of Holt-Oram syndrome was delayed and the cardiac defects have been revealed at the stage of surgery. We will discuss the variables of the musculoskeletal abnormalities and their association with the cardiac morphological defects.Conclusion: Holt-Oram syndrome is a rare inherited clinical disorder. Cardiac defect should be suspected in the presence of congenital upper limb abnormalities.</dc:description><dc:publisher xml:lang="en-US">Mediterranean Journals</dc:publisher><dc:date>2015-06-30</dc:date><dc:type>info:eu-repo/semantics/article</dc:type><dc:type>info:eu-repo/semantics/publishedVersion</dc:type><dc:format>application/pdf</dc:format><dc:identifier>https://www.mbmj.org/index.php/ijms/article/view/20</dc:identifier><dc:identifier>10.15342/ijms.v2i1.63</dc:identifier><dc:source xml:lang="en-US">Integrative Journal of Medical Sciences; Vol. 2 No. 1 (2015); 16-18</dc:source><dc:source>2658-8218</dc:source><dc:language>eng</dc:language><dc:relation>https://www.mbmj.org/index.php/ijms/article/view/20/344</dc:relation><dc:rights xml:lang="en-US">Copyright (c) 2015 Abderrahmane Bakkali et al.</dc:rights><dc:rights xml:lang="en-US">https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/</dc:rights></oai_dc:dc></metadata></record><record xmlns="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"><header><identifier>oai:ojs2.173.212.231.62:article/21</identifier><datestamp>2020-05-06T21:23:23Z</datestamp><setSpec>ijms:CR</setSpec><setSpec>driver</setSpec></header><metadata><oai_dc:dc xmlns:oai_dc="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/" xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/  http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc.xsd"><dc:title xml:lang="en-US">Bilateral acetabular fracture. Two case reports with literature review</dc:title><dc:creator>Boussakri, Hassan</dc:creator><dc:creator>Elibrahimi, Abdelhalim ElIBRAHIMI</dc:creator><dc:creator>Elidrissi, Mohammed</dc:creator><dc:creator>Shimi, Mohammed</dc:creator><dc:creator>Elmrini, Abdelmajid</dc:creator><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Bilateral</dc:subject><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Acetabular</dc:subject><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Fracture</dc:subject><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Internal fixation</dc:subject><dc:description xml:lang="en-US">Bilateral acetabular fractures represent a challenge, even for experienced Orthopedic surgeons&amp;nbsp;.We present two patients who had an isolated acetabular bilateral fracture, following a violent trauma caused by a traffic accident, which were treated in our department .The treatment strategy is planned by a team of surgeons. After a proper preoperative preparation and using a surgical treatment by postero-lateral Moore and Kocher-Langenbeck approach with internal fixation. Our clinical and radiological results were very satisfying.</dc:description><dc:publisher xml:lang="en-US">Mediterranean Journals</dc:publisher><dc:date>2015-06-30</dc:date><dc:type>info:eu-repo/semantics/article</dc:type><dc:type>info:eu-repo/semantics/publishedVersion</dc:type><dc:format>application/pdf</dc:format><dc:identifier>https://www.mbmj.org/index.php/ijms/article/view/21</dc:identifier><dc:identifier>10.15342/ijms.v2i1.17</dc:identifier><dc:source xml:lang="en-US">Integrative Journal of Medical Sciences; Vol. 2 No. 1 (2015); 19-22</dc:source><dc:source>2658-8218</dc:source><dc:language>eng</dc:language><dc:relation>https://www.mbmj.org/index.php/ijms/article/view/21/345</dc:relation><dc:rights xml:lang="en-US">Copyright (c) 2015 Hassan Boussakri et al.</dc:rights><dc:rights xml:lang="en-US">https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/</dc:rights></oai_dc:dc></metadata></record><record xmlns="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"><header><identifier>oai:ojs2.173.212.231.62:article/22</identifier><datestamp>2020-05-06T21:23:23Z</datestamp><setSpec>ijms:CR</setSpec><setSpec>driver</setSpec></header><metadata><oai_dc:dc xmlns:oai_dc="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/" xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/  http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc.xsd"><dc:title xml:lang="en-US">Myasthenia Revealed Following Laparotomy - A Case Report</dc:title><dc:creator>Ghannan, Abdelilah</dc:creator><dc:creator>Tazi, Abdellah</dc:creator><dc:creator>Tadili, Jawad</dc:creator><dc:creator>Faroudy,  Mamoun</dc:creator><dc:creator>Kettani, Ali</dc:creator><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Myasthenia</dc:subject><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Ventilatory weaning</dc:subject><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Postoperative respiratory complications</dc:subject><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Anesthesia</dc:subject><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Neuromuscular disease</dc:subject><dc:description xml:lang="en-US">Myasthenia (muscle weakness) is a rare neuromuscular disease of which respiratory failure is the main complication. The accidental discovery of such disease in the perioperative period is rare and potentially serious.We report a case of a woman who underwent emergency operation for appendiceal peritonitis, and failed repeatedly at weaning from postoperative mechanical ventilation. The usual etiologies such as postoperative respiratory complications, ventilator-associated pneumonia, acute respiratory distress syndrome complicating the septic shock or having no impact on it, and neuromyopathy’s resuscitation were considered, researched, examined or eliminated.Faced with the diagnostic impasse and the obvious weaning failure, another interview revealed signs of muscle fatigue which led to the diagnosis of myasthenia gravis decompensated perioperatively. Once the diagnosis was confirmed by means of a neostigmine test, the specific treatment began, particularly through plasma exchange sessions, and the process of weaning resumed. The result was complete weaning. A three-month follow-up showed a stable patient with no significant muscular disability.</dc:description><dc:publisher xml:lang="en-US">Mediterranean Journals</dc:publisher><dc:date>2015-06-30</dc:date><dc:type>info:eu-repo/semantics/article</dc:type><dc:type>info:eu-repo/semantics/publishedVersion</dc:type><dc:format>application/pdf</dc:format><dc:identifier>https://www.mbmj.org/index.php/ijms/article/view/22</dc:identifier><dc:identifier>10.15342/ijms.v2i1.16</dc:identifier><dc:source xml:lang="en-US">Integrative Journal of Medical Sciences; Vol. 2 No. 1 (2015); 23-25</dc:source><dc:source>2658-8218</dc:source><dc:language>eng</dc:language><dc:relation>https://www.mbmj.org/index.php/ijms/article/view/22/346</dc:relation><dc:rights xml:lang="en-US">Copyright (c) 2015 Abdelilah Ghannam et al.</dc:rights><dc:rights xml:lang="en-US">https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/</dc:rights></oai_dc:dc></metadata></record><record xmlns="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"><header><identifier>oai:ojs2.173.212.231.62:article/23</identifier><datestamp>2020-05-06T21:23:23Z</datestamp><setSpec>ijms:IMG</setSpec><setSpec>driver</setSpec></header><metadata><oai_dc:dc xmlns:oai_dc="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/" xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/  http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc.xsd"><dc:title xml:lang="en-US">Penile cavernous hemangioma</dc:title><dc:creator>Echchaoui, Abdelmoughit</dc:creator><dc:creator>Zaouri, Hasna</dc:creator><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Cavernous hemangioma</dc:subject><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Penis</dc:subject><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Management</dc:subject><dc:description xml:lang="en-US">Hemangiomas are benign lesions that occur in any part of the body in newborns or in young patients, they are typically capillary or cavernous. Cavernous hemangioma of the penis is extremely rare; and its etiology is not completely understood. Treatment options (surgical excision, laser therapy or sclerotherapy…) are controversial and are required if pain, cosmetic defect and/or bleeding during intercourse.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;
We report a case of a 26 years old man presented with a five years history of a painless lesion on his penis. Physical examination showed an ovoid, solid, 1 x 2 mm in size on the dorsum of penis (Panel A) and two elevated irregular lesions on the ventral side (Panel B). The lesions were compressive, nonpulsatile and bluish-red in color with strawberry like appearance. Biopsy and histopathological examination of the lesion revealed a gaping and communicating vessels proliferated in the superficial and medium dermis which is pathognomonic for cavernous hemangioma (Panel C and D). Given the small size, the large number of the lesions, the young age, and the ulceration risk during intercourse if skin graft after excision, Neodymium: YAG laser coagulation was recommended to get a good cosmetic results and sexual function satisfaction.</dc:description><dc:publisher xml:lang="en-US">Mediterranean Journals</dc:publisher><dc:date>2015-06-30</dc:date><dc:type>info:eu-repo/semantics/article</dc:type><dc:type>info:eu-repo/semantics/publishedVersion</dc:type><dc:format>application/pdf</dc:format><dc:identifier>https://www.mbmj.org/index.php/ijms/article/view/23</dc:identifier><dc:identifier>10.15342/ijms.v2i1.60</dc:identifier><dc:source xml:lang="en-US">Integrative Journal of Medical Sciences;
