It has been suggested that this reaction during appropriate treatment is common and severe in HIV-negative individuals. Our objective was to determine the frequency of paradoxical reactions and their associated features. Method :&amp;nbsp;A prospective study was undertaken in a population of HIV-TB+ patients to determine the frequency of paradoxical reactions and their associated features. Results:&amp;nbsp;Paradoxical reactions occurred in 1.5% of all our hospital’s TB patients.&amp;nbsp;Conclusion :&amp;nbsp;Paradoxical reactions during anti-TB treatment is common in HIV-uninfected individuals and must be considered after careful exclusion of medication non-adherence, other infections, development of resistance, and other similar conditions.</dc:description><dc:publisher xml:lang="en-US">Mediterranean Journals</dc:publisher><dc:date>2015-01-30</dc:date><dc:type>info:eu-repo/semantics/article</dc:type><dc:type>info:eu-repo/semantics/publishedVersion</dc:type><dc:format>application/pdf</dc:format><dc:identifier>https://www.mbmj.org/index.php/ijms/article/view/24</dc:identifier><dc:identifier>10.15342/ijms.v2i2.75</dc:identifier><dc:source xml:lang="en-US">Integrative Journal of Medical Sciences; Vol. 2 No. 2 (2015); 32-35</dc:source><dc:source>2658-8218</dc:source><dc:language>eng</dc:language><dc:relation>https://www.mbmj.org/index.php/ijms/article/view/24/349</dc:relation><dc:rights xml:lang="en-US">Copyright (c) 2015 Sanae Hammi et al.</dc:rights><dc:rights xml:lang="en-US">https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/</dc:rights></oai_dc:dc></metadata></record><record xmlns="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"><header><identifier>oai:ojs2.173.212.231.62:article/25</identifier><datestamp>2020-05-06T21:17:03Z</datestamp><setSpec>ijms:ART</setSpec><setSpec>driver</setSpec></header><metadata><oai_dc:dc xmlns:oai_dc="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/" xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/  http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc.xsd"><dc:title xml:lang="en-US">Risk Factors for Diabetic Foot in Tetouan, Morocco - A Case-Control Study</dc:title><dc:creator>Aoufi, Hicham</dc:creator><dc:creator>Mouwafaq, Safouane</dc:creator><dc:creator>Likos, A</dc:creator><dc:creator>Maaroufi, Abderrahmane</dc:creator><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Diabetes</dc:subject><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Diabetic foot</dc:subject><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Case-control</dc:subject><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">OR</dc:subject><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Tetouan</dc:subject><dc:description xml:lang="en-US">Introduction Diabetes is a globally major public health problem. Its evolution is insidious and silent before the appearance of serious complications as a consequence in terms of morbidity than of mortality. Complications in the feet are among the most frequent and feared. This study helps identify factors associated with diabetic foot in diabetic patients in the province of Tetouan in public and private sector.Methods This is a case-control study in which 136 diabetic patients monitored in the public and private sector in the province of Tetouan were chosen. 68 patients had diabetic foot and 68 were diabetic patients without this complication. Data were collected from patients’ records and supplemented by interviews. The factors compared between the two groups were sociodemographic, biological and related to diabetes and lifestyle. These risk factors were determined by bivariate and multivariate analyses.Results Statistically significant associations were found between diabetic foot and several factors including: the irregular monitoring of patients: ORadjusted = 7.7 [1.9-23], the rate of glycated hemoglobin: ORadjusted = 1.7 [1.2-2.3], diabetes duration: ORadjusted = 1.2 [1.03-1.26], and physical activity ORadjusted = 1.1 [0.02-0.9]. However, no association was found between diabetic foot and the level of education or occupation.Conclusion To prevent the development of diabetic foot, more attention should be given to diabetic patients whose diabetes duration is long, patient monitoring should be regular and diabetes control should be optimal. In addition, physical activity is recommended for diabetic patients as part of promoting healthy lifestyles.</dc:description><dc:publisher xml:lang="en-US">Mediterranean Journals</dc:publisher><dc:date>2015-01-30</dc:date><dc:type>info:eu-repo/semantics/article</dc:type><dc:type>info:eu-repo/semantics/publishedVersion</dc:type><dc:format>application/pdf</dc:format><dc:identifier>https://www.mbmj.org/index.php/ijms/article/view/25</dc:identifier><dc:identifier>10.15342/ijms.v2i2.79</dc:identifier><dc:source xml:lang="en-US">Integrative Journal of Medical Sciences; Vol. 2 No. 2 (2015); 27-31</dc:source><dc:source>2658-8218</dc:source><dc:language>eng</dc:language><dc:relation>https://www.mbmj.org/index.php/ijms/article/view/25/377</dc:relation><dc:rights xml:lang="en-US">Copyright (c) 2015 Hicham Aoufi et al.</dc:rights><dc:rights xml:lang="en-US">https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/</dc:rights></oai_dc:dc></metadata></record><record xmlns="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"><header><identifier>oai:ojs2.173.212.231.62:article/26</identifier><datestamp>2020-05-06T21:17:03Z</datestamp><setSpec>ijms:ART</setSpec><setSpec>driver</setSpec></header><metadata><oai_dc:dc xmlns:oai_dc="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/" xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/  http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc.xsd"><dc:title xml:lang="en-US">Treatment Results Of Diaphyseal Forearm Fractures With Dynamique Compression Plate A Retrospective study of 156 Cases.</dc:title><dc:creator>Boussakri, Hassan</dc:creator><dc:creator>Bouziane Ouaritini, Ahmed</dc:creator><dc:creator>Shimi, Mohammed</dc:creator><dc:creator>Elidrissi, Mohammed</dc:creator><dc:creator>Elibrahimi, Abdelhalim</dc:creator><dc:creator>Elmrini, Abdelmajid</dc:creator><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Forearm</dc:subject><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Shaft fracture</dc:subject><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Dynamic compression plate</dc:subject><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Clinical and radiological results</dc:subject><dc:description xml:lang="en-US">This retrospective study addresses a series of 156 cases of forearm fractures. These 156 cases were managed in the trauma-orthopedic department (B4) of Fez University Hospital, Morocco, from May 2008 till January 2013. The purpose of this study is to analyze epidemiological and clinical factors of diaphyseal forearm fractures and the results of their treatment with dynamic compression plate (DCP), as well as the complications and therapeutic errors of this surgical technique. The frequency of hospitalization in the trauma-orthopedic department was 3,96%. Ages ranged between 16 and 83, the average age was 32. 132 patients were male (85%). 90% were managed at the day of trauma. Traffic accidents were the most frequent cause in 52% patients. The fracture was in the left forearm in 65% of patients. 53% of fracture lines were in the middle third of the forearm. 38 fractures were open, and 30 were admitted for polytrauma. Osteosynthesis was performed with dynamic compression plate for all patients. In comparison with the literature, our series shows the predominance of young male patients, with traffic accidents being the cause. Osteosynthesis with dynamic compression plate remains the treatment of choice that provides satisfactory results if the accuracy in this technique was respected.</dc:description><dc:publisher xml:lang="en-US">Mediterranean Journals</dc:publisher><dc:date>2015-01-30</dc:date><dc:type>info:eu-repo/semantics/article</dc:type><dc:type>info:eu-repo/semantics/publishedVersion</dc:type><dc:format>application/pdf</dc:format><dc:identifier>https://www.mbmj.org/index.php/ijms/article/view/26</dc:identifier><dc:identifier>10.15342/ijms.v2i2.51</dc:identifier><dc:source xml:lang="en-US">Integrative Journal of Medical Sciences; Vol. 2 No. 2 (2015); 36-39</dc:source><dc:source>2658-8218</dc:source><dc:language>eng</dc:language><dc:relation>https://www.mbmj.org/index.php/ijms/article/view/26/350</dc:relation><dc:rights xml:lang="en-US">Copyright (c) 2015 Hassan Boussakri et al.</dc:rights><dc:rights xml:lang="en-US">https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/</dc:rights></oai_dc:dc></metadata></record><record xmlns="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"><header><identifier>oai:ojs2.173.212.231.62:article/27</identifier><datestamp>2020-05-06T21:17:03Z</datestamp><setSpec>ijms:ART</setSpec><setSpec>driver</setSpec></header><metadata><oai_dc:dc xmlns:oai_dc="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/" xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/  http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc.xsd"><dc:title xml:lang="en-US">Tuberculosis of The Parotid Gland in Children - A Report of 4 Cases</dc:title><dc:creator>Borki, Rajae </dc:creator><dc:creator>Bouti, Khalid </dc:creator><dc:creator>Lahma, Jawad</dc:creator><dc:creator>Bouadel, Noureddine</dc:creator><dc:creator>Rkain, Ilham</dc:creator><dc:creator>Nitassi, Sophia</dc:creator><dc:creator>El Ayoubi, Ali</dc:creator><dc:creator>Bencheikh, Razika</dc:creator><dc:creator>Benbouzid, Anass</dc:creator><dc:creator>Essakalli, Leila</dc:creator><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Parotid gland</dc:subject><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Children</dc:subject><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Tuberculosis</dc:subject><dc:description xml:lang="en-US">Tuberculosis is a chronic granulomatous infection caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis or bovis that can affect all organs. However being located in the salivary glands is rare, affecting mainly adults between 20 and 50 years, although a few cases were described in children. We reported a series of 4 children with parotid TB diagnosed and treated at the ENT department of the hospital of specialties of Rabat.The average age was 9.25 years and sex ratio M/F was 1. All children were admitted for parotid swelling evolving over an average period of 6 months which fistulized afterwards, a child had also facial paralysis. Histological analysis of the fine-needle aspiration or the sample taken from the fistula confirmed the diagnosis of tuberculosis with the presence of giant cell granuloma with caseous necrosis. All children received anti-bacillary treatment during 6 months, and showed good evolution.Although being rare, the parotid TB in children remains a condition to be considered at the occurrence of any chronic parotid swelling, especially in endemic countries.</dc:description><dc:publisher xml:lang="en-US">Mediterranean Journals</dc:publisher><dc:date>2015-01-30</dc:date><dc:type>info:eu-repo/semantics/article</dc:type><dc:type>info:eu-repo/semantics/publishedVersion</dc:type><dc:format>application/pdf</dc:format><dc:identifier>https://www.mbmj.org/index.php/ijms/article/view/27</dc:identifier><dc:identifier>10.15342/ijms.v2i2.78</dc:identifier><dc:source xml:lang="en-US">Integrative Journal of Medical Sciences; Vol. 2 No. 2 (2015); 40-43</dc:source><dc:source>2658-8218</dc:source><dc:language>eng</dc:language><dc:relation>https://www.mbmj.org/index.php/ijms/article/view/27/351</dc:relation><dc:rights xml:lang="en-US">Copyright (c) 2015 Rajae Borki et al.</dc:rights><dc:rights xml:lang="en-US">https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/</dc:rights></oai_dc:dc></metadata></record><record xmlns="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"><header><identifier>oai:ojs2.173.212.231.62:article/28</identifier><datestamp>2020-05-06T21:17:03Z</datestamp><setSpec>ijms:PERS</setSpec><setSpec>driver</setSpec></header><metadata><oai_dc:dc xmlns:oai_dc="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/" xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/  http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc.xsd"><dc:title xml:lang="en-US">Syphilis in Colonial Morocco - The Case of Bousbir</dc:title><dc:creator>Laboudi, Fouad </dc:creator><dc:creator>Mehssani, Jamal </dc:creator><dc:creator>Ragoug, Allal </dc:creator><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Bousbir</dc:subject><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Morocco</dc:subject><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Venereal diseases</dc:subject><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Syphilis</dc:subject><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Protectorate</dc:subject><dc:description xml:lang="en-US">Syphilis is a venereal disease. Morocco has witnessed syphilis since the fifteenth century and the treatment of this disease remained archaic until the Protectorate was established.With the establishment of the colonial system in Morocco, the phenomenon of prostitution spread. Protectorate authorities designated a particular place in Casablanca for such activity that developed: Bousbir district. The authorities’ efforts failed to regulate and organize such activity because of the development of clandestine prostitution in relation to urban growth and the increase of employed, poor and downgraded urban population, especially among women who practice prostitution, and due to lack of a real social policy of the Protectorate concerning the policy of land-use planning or control that were a priority.&amp;nbsp;</dc:description><dc:publisher xml:lang="en-US">Mediterranean Journals</dc:publisher><dc:date>2015-01-30</dc:date><dc:type>info:eu-repo/semantics/article</dc:type><dc:type>info:eu-repo/semantics/publishedVersion</dc:type><dc:format>application/pdf</dc:format><dc:identifier>https://www.mbmj.org/index.php/ijms/article/view/28</dc:identifier><dc:identifier>10.15342/ijms.v2i2.65</dc:identifier><dc:source xml:lang="en-US">Integrative Journal of Medical Sciences; Vol. 2 No. 2 (2015); 44-46</dc:source><dc:source>2658-8218</dc:source><dc:language>eng</dc:language><dc:relation>https://www.mbmj.org/index.php/ijms/article/view/28/354</dc:relation><dc:rights xml:lang="en-US">Copyright (c) 2015 Fouad Laboudi et al.</dc:rights><dc:rights xml:lang="en-US">https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/</dc:rights></oai_dc:dc></metadata></record><record xmlns="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"><header><identifier>oai:ojs2.173.212.231.62:article/29</identifier><datestamp>2020-05-06T21:17:03Z</datestamp><setSpec>ijms:CR</setSpec><setSpec>driver</setSpec></header><metadata><oai_dc:dc xmlns:oai_dc="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/" xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/  http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc.xsd"><dc:title xml:lang="en-US">Fatal Cardiothyreosis Revealed Through A Status Epilepticus And Resulting In A Therapeutic Impasse - A Case Report</dc:title><dc:creator>Ghannam, Abdelilah</dc:creator><dc:creator>Ouassou, Zakaria</dc:creator><dc:creator>Tadili, Jawad</dc:creator><dc:creator>Kettani, Ali</dc:creator><dc:creator>Faroudy, Mamoun</dc:creator><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Cardiothyreosis</dc:subject><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Thyroid disease</dc:subject><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Status epilepticus</dc:subject><dc:description xml:lang="en-US">Cardiothyreosis is a rare and serious complication of thyroid disease. We report a case that is unique in its inaugural clinical picture (status epilepticus) due to late diagnosis and iatrogenic drug which precipitated the patient in an array of congestive heart failure where therapeutic management was limited by insufficient technical facilities leading to death.</dc:description><dc:publisher xml:lang="en-US">Mediterranean Journals</dc:publisher><dc:date>2015-01-30</dc:date><dc:type>info:eu-repo/semantics/article</dc:type><dc:type>info:eu-repo/semantics/publishedVersion</dc:type><dc:format>application/pdf</dc:format><dc:identifier>https://www.mbmj.org/index.php/ijms/article/view/29</dc:identifier><dc:identifier>10.15342/ijms.v2i2.38</dc:identifier><dc:source xml:lang="en-US">Integrative Journal of Medical Sciences; Vol. 2 No. 2 (2015); 47-48</dc:source><dc:source>2658-8218</dc:source><dc:language>eng</dc:language><dc:relation>https://www.mbmj.org/index.php/ijms/article/view/29/352</dc:relation><dc:rights xml:lang="en-US">Copyright (c) 2015 Abdelilah Ghannam et al.</dc:rights><dc:rights xml:lang="en-US">https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/</dc:rights></oai_dc:dc></metadata></record><record xmlns="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"><header><identifier>oai:ojs2.173.212.231.62:article/30</identifier><datestamp>2020-05-06T21:17:03Z</datestamp><setSpec>ijms:IMG</setSpec><setSpec>driver</setSpec></header><metadata><oai_dc:dc xmlns:oai_dc="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/" xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/  http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc.xsd"><dc:title xml:lang="en-US">Ashy dermatosis : A case of cinderella</dc:title><dc:creator>Zaouri, Hasnaa</dc:creator><dc:creator>Hassam, Badreddine</dc:creator><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Ashy dermatosis</dc:subject><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Erythema perstans dyschromicum</dc:subject><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Hypermelanosis</dc:subject><dc:description xml:lang="en-US">We report the case of a 20-years old female, who presented anasymptomatic&amp;nbsp; grayish macules affecting the neck, trunk and roots of legs (Panel A). Histopathologic examination showed &amp;nbsp;an increased dermal melanophages (Panel B) and a vacuolization of basal cell layer (Panel C), evoking an ashy dermatosis (AD). Paraclinical assessment didn't find any related&amp;nbsp; disease. Multiple therapy was proposed such as corticosteroids andphototherapy. Evolution was marked by the extension of&amp;nbsp; lesions in members at five years of follow-up.AD was first described by Ramírez. He called the patients «Los cenicientos». The Spanish term cenicienta means Cinderella, because of this folklore character's close association with ashes from sitting at &amp;nbsp;home alone by the fireplace. Most cases present&amp;nbsp; gray–brown macules which are commonly found on the face, arms, neck, and trunk. Histopathologic findings are nonspecific and include vacuolization of the basal layer, pigmentary incontinence and perivascular inflammatory infiltrate. The etiology of AD is unknown. Some authors reported associations with ammonium nitrate, whipworm infestation and HIV seroconversions. Many treatments was proposed such as corticosteroids, dapsone, clofazimine and phototherapy, but the results are not satisfactory. Such as basic research on the pathogenesis and treatment of hypermelanosis continuous, we look for more answers to the questions raised by this case.</dc:description><dc:publisher xml:lang="en-US">Mediterranean Journals</dc:publisher><dc:date>2015-01-30</dc:date><dc:type>info:eu-repo/semantics/article</dc:type><dc:type>info:eu-repo/semantics/publishedVersion</dc:type><dc:format>application/pdf</dc:format><dc:identifier>https://www.mbmj.org/index.php/ijms/article/view/30</dc:identifier><dc:identifier>10.15342/ijms.v2i2.64</dc:identifier><dc:source xml:lang="en-US">Integrative Journal of Medical Sciences; Vol. 2 No. 2 (2015); 49</dc:source><dc:source>2658-8218</dc:source><dc:language>eng</dc:language><dc:relation>https://www.mbmj.org/index.php/ijms/article/view/30/353</dc:relation><dc:rights xml:lang="en-US">Copyright (c) 2015 Hasnaa Zaouri and Badreddine Hassam</dc:rights><dc:rights xml:lang="en-US">https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/</dc:rights></oai_dc:dc></metadata></record><record xmlns="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"><header><identifier>oai:ojs2.173.212.231.62:article/31</identifier><datestamp>2020-05-06T22:55:22Z</datestamp><setSpec>ijms:ART</setSpec><setSpec>driver</setSpec></header><metadata><oai_dc:dc xmlns:oai_dc="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/" xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/  http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc.xsd"><dc:title xml:lang="en-US">Relationship Between Disease Activity and Hearing Loss in Rheumatoid Arthritis Patients A Case Control Study</dc:title><dc:creator>Rkain, Ilham</dc:creator><dc:creator>Rkain, Hanan</dc:creator><dc:creator>Bouaddi, Ilham</dc:creator><dc:creator>Dakka, Taoufik</dc:creator><dc:creator>Hajjaj-Hassouni, Najia</dc:creator><dc:creator>Essakalli, Leila</dc:creator><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Rheumatoid arthritis</dc:subject><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Hearing loss</dc:subject><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Disease activity</dc:subject><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">DAS 28</dc:subject><dc:description xml:lang="en-US">Objectives :&amp;nbsp;Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is well known to affect many different organ systems. Previous work suggests that this includes the auditory system.&amp;nbsp;The objectives of this work are to evaluate the pattern of hearing impairment in patients with rheumatoid arthritis and also to examine the possible associations between hearing impairment and related RA features especially disease activity.&amp;nbsp;Materials and methods :&amp;nbsp;Thirty RA patients (mean age of 44.5 ± 9.9 years; female sex (90%)) and 17 healthy controls (mean age of 41.5±9.1 years; female sex (76.4%)) were included in our study. The 2 groups were matched for age and sex (p&amp;gt;0.05). Otoscopic examination was normal in all participants.&amp;nbsp;No subject of the 2 groups has had any abnormalities at otoscopic examination. Hearing impairment was evaluated by pure tone audiometry and tympanometry including the static compliance, middle ear pressure, stapedial reflex threshold test. In all patients the clinical features, laboratory data, X-rays, disease activity index-DAS 28 were performed.&amp;nbsp;Results :&amp;nbsp;Hearing loss was more prevalent in RA patients compared to healthy controls (56.7 vs 11.8%; p=0.005). RA patients have conductive, sensorineural and mixed hearing loss in respectively 43.4, 3.3 and 10 % of cases. Association analysis between hearing characteristics and remission in RA patients shows that RA patients in remission have significantly lower mean hearing thresholds (12.8±5.2dB vs 18.8±6.9 dB ; p=0.04).&amp;nbsp;Conclusion :&amp;nbsp;This study suggests that hearing loss risk is higher in RA patients and seems to be associated to disease duration. Hearing loss in RA was directly proportional to the disease activity index-DAS 28. Audiological evaluation must be performed periodically to identify possible audiological damage.</dc:description><dc:publisher xml:lang="en-US">Mediterranean Journals</dc:publisher><dc:date>2016-01-30</dc:date><dc:type>info:eu-repo/semantics/article</dc:type><dc:type>info:eu-repo/semantics/publishedVersion</dc:type><dc:format>application/pdf</dc:format><dc:identifier>https://www.mbmj.org/index.php/ijms/article/view/31</dc:identifier><dc:identifier>10.15342/ijms.v3i1.86</dc:identifier><dc:source xml:lang="en-US">Integrative Journal of Medical Sciences; Vol. 3 No. 1 (2016); 1-5</dc:source><dc:source>2658-8218</dc:source><dc:language>eng</dc:language><dc:relation>https://www.mbmj.org/index.php/ijms/article/view/31/355</dc:relation><dc:rights xml:lang="en-US">Copyright (c) 2016 Ilham Rkain et al.</dc:rights><dc:rights xml:lang="en-US">https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/</dc:rights></oai_dc:dc></metadata></record><record xmlns="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"><header><identifier>oai:ojs2.173.212.231.62:article/32</identifier><datestamp>2020-05-06T22:55:47Z</datestamp><setSpec>ijms:ART</setSpec><setSpec>driver</setSpec></header><metadata><oai_dc:dc xmlns:oai_dc="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/" xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/  http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc.xsd"><dc:title xml:lang="en-US">Using In-Hospital Mortality as an Indicator of Quality Care and Hospital Performance</dc:title><dc:creator>Bisbis, Badia</dc:creator><dc:creator>El Gamri, Abdelhai</dc:creator><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">in-hospital mortality</dc:subject><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Al Farabi hospital</dc:subject><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Oujda</dc:subject><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Quality care</dc:subject><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Indicator</dc:subject><dc:description xml:lang="en-US">The in-hospital mortality (MIH) is used as a performance indicator and quality healthcare in hospital. However, the majority of deaths resulted from an inevitable disease process (severity of cases and / or co-morbidity), and not medical errors or changes in the quality of care. This work aims to make a distribution of deaths in the Regional Hospital of Eastern, Al Farabi hospital and to highlight that more studies on the MIH are required consistently with detailed clinical data at the admission. The MIH showed its limitation as a health care&amp;nbsp; indicator. The overall rate of in-hospital deaths within the Al Farabi hospital has averaged 2.4%, with 8.4% in the emergency unit, 28% in intensive care unit, 22% Neonatology unit, 1.6% in pediatric unit. The MIH may depend, firstly, on the condition of patients before hospitalization and secondly, on the conditions of their transfer from one institution to another that supports them as a last resort. Al Farabi hospital supports patients transferred from the provinces of the eastern region. Thus, 6% of patients who died in 2014 come from Berkane, 2% from&amp;nbsp; Nador, 2% from Bouarfa, 4% from&amp;nbsp; Taourirt and 2% from Jerrada. One might question about&amp;nbsp; the procedures and the conditions of such transfers. In conclusion, the overall MIH measured from routine data do not allow proper comparison between hospitals or the assessment of the quality of care and patient safety in the hospital. To do so, we should ideally have detailed clinical data on admission (e.g. type of admission, age of patient, sex, comorbidity, ...). The MIH is however an important indicator to consider as a tool to detect potential&amp;nbsp; problems related to admission procedures and to suspect an area of "non-quality" in healthcare . The MIH is interesting for the patient and for the hospital because it serves the improvement of quality healthcare.</dc:description><dc:publisher xml:lang="en-US">Mediterranean Journals</dc:publisher><dc:date>2016-01-30</dc:date><dc:type>info:eu-repo/semantics/article</dc:type><dc:type>info:eu-repo/semantics/publishedVersion</dc:type><dc:format>application/pdf</dc:format><dc:identifier>https://www.mbmj.org/index.php/ijms/article/view/32</dc:identifier><dc:identifier>10.15342/ijms.v3i1.77</dc:identifier><dc:source xml:lang="en-US">Integrative Journal of Medical Sciences; In Morocco, TDM is not routinely used, yet low levels of anti-TB drugs can be associated with poorer treatment outcomes.&amp;nbsp;Methods:&amp;nbsp;We retrospectively checked our archives for patients with active TB for whom TDM was performed during 2014. Medical records were reviewed to abstract demographic, clinical, radiographic and microbiological data including time until smear and culture conversion. Then, we looked for cases with delay of TB conversion.Results:&amp;nbsp;In total, 24 patients were identified, for whom TDM was performed, they all had low serum drug levels. Among them, 4 patients showed delayed bacteriological conversion.Conclusions:&amp;nbsp;Our study cases are showing the benefit of serum dosage in the follow-up of the patients showing a delay of sputum examination conversion, both direct and culture, during their evolutions. TDM is potentially useful for the treatment of active TB, but is currently underused in Morocco.</dc:description><dc:publisher xml:lang="en-US">Mediterranean Journals</dc:publisher><dc:date>2016-01-30</dc:date><dc:type>info:eu-repo/semantics/article</dc:type><dc:type>info:eu-repo/semantics/publishedVersion</dc:type><dc:format>application/pdf</dc:format><dc:identifier>https://www.mbmj.org/index.php/ijms/article/view/33</dc:identifier><dc:identifier>10.15342/ijms.v3i1.92</dc:identifier><dc:source xml:lang="en-US">Integrative Journal of Medical Sciences; For this, we have made three videos on the implementation of shaped clasps, while fixing the duration of the films successively at 8min50, 5min05 and 3min30. The videos were evaluated by the entire class through a questionnaire distributed to students who were present in the practical work training session. The biostatistical analysis revealed the preference to be for the 8min50 video with an initial viewing percentage of 59.3%. At a second and another viewing, preference was successively in favor of the 5min05 video (54.5%) and that of 3min 30 (43.4%). Furthermore, the students’ favorite videos were those with a time interval of 10 to 20 minutes (46.9%) for upcoming educational materials.</dc:description><dc:publisher xml:lang="en-US">Mediterranean Journals</dc:publisher><dc:date>2016-01-30</dc:date><dc:type>info:eu-repo/semantics/article</dc:type><dc:type>info:eu-repo/semantics/publishedVersion</dc:type><dc:format>application/pdf</dc:format><dc:identifier>https://www.mbmj.org/index.php/ijms/article/view/34</dc:identifier><dc:identifier>10.15342/ijms.v2i2.72</dc:identifier><dc:source xml:lang="en-US">Integrative Journal of Medical Sciences; Vol. 3 No. 1 (2016); 13-17</dc:source><dc:source>2658-8218</dc:source><dc:language>eng</dc:language><dc:relation>https://www.mbmj.org/index.php/ijms/article/view/34/359</dc:relation><dc:rights xml:lang="en-US">Copyright (c) 2016 Anissa Regragui et al.</dc:rights><dc:rights xml:lang="en-US">https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/</dc:rights></oai_dc:dc></metadata></record><record xmlns="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"><header><identifier>oai:ojs2.173.212.231.62:article/35</identifier><datestamp>2020-05-06T22:57:01Z</datestamp><setSpec>ijms:ART</setSpec><setSpec>driver</setSpec></header><metadata><oai_dc:dc xmlns:oai_dc="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/" xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/  http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc.xsd"><dc:title xml:lang="en-US">Three Weekly Irinotecan and Bolus 5-Fluorouracil Combination in the First Line Treatment of Advanced Gastric Cancer - A Single Institution Experience</dc:title><dc:creator>Mesmoudi, Mohamed</dc:creator><dc:creator>Mahfoud, Tarik </dc:creator><dc:creator>Ahid, Samir</dc:creator><dc:creator>Ismaili, Nabil</dc:creator><dc:creator>Boutayeb, Saber</dc:creator><dc:creator>Errihani, Hassan</dc:creator><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Advanced gastric cancer</dc:subject><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Irinotecan</dc:subject><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Bolus 5-FU</dc:subject><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">First line treatment</dc:subject><dc:description xml:lang="en-US">Background:&amp;nbsp;The goal of this study is to determine the efficacy and toxicity of a non-platinum based chemotherapy combination using irinotecan associated to bolus 5-FU as first line treatment in advanced gastric cancer.&amp;nbsp;Materiel and methods:&amp;nbsp;Retrospective analysis of a population of patients treated for metastatic and locally advanced gastric cancer with irinotecan and 5-FU as upfront chemotherapy.&amp;nbsp;Results:&amp;nbsp;Thirteen patients were enrolled. The median age was 56 years. Seven patients were males and six were of females. Ten patients had a metastatic disease and three patients had a locally advanced disease. Patients received a total number of 43 cycles of chemotherapy. Overall response rate was&amp;nbsp;38,4%, median time to progression (TTP) was 3 months, and median overall survival was 4 months. Three patients (23,1%) presented grade 3 /4 neutropenia complicated with an infectious episode with fever in two cases, three patients (23,1%) required blood transfusion for a grade 4 anemia, and one patient (7,6%) was hospitalized for a severe episode of diarrhea.&amp;nbsp;Conclusion:&amp;nbsp;Three weekly irinotecan and bolus 5-FU is an interesting combination as first line treatment of advanced gastric cancer; designed clinical trials are needed to confirm the activity of this combination.</dc:description><dc:publisher xml:lang="en-US">Mediterranean Journals</dc:publisher><dc:date>2016-01-30</dc:date><dc:type>info:eu-repo/semantics/article</dc:type><dc:type>info:eu-repo/semantics/publishedVersion</dc:type><dc:format>application/pdf</dc:format><dc:identifier>https://www.mbmj.org/index.php/ijms/article/view/35</dc:identifier><dc:identifier>10.15342/ijms.v3i1.95</dc:identifier><dc:source xml:lang="en-US">Integrative Journal of Medical Sciences; Vol. 3 No. 1 (2016); 18-21</dc:source><dc:source>2658-8218</dc:source><dc:language>eng</dc:language><dc:relation>https://www.mbmj.org/index.php/ijms/article/view/35/358</dc:relation><dc:rights xml:lang="en-US">Copyright (c) 2016 Mohamed Mesmoudi et al.</dc:rights><dc:rights xml:lang="en-US">https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/</dc:rights></oai_dc:dc></metadata></record><record xmlns="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"><header><identifier>oai:ojs2.173.212.231.62:article/36</identifier><datestamp>2020-05-06T22:57:33Z</datestamp><setSpec>ijms:Rev</setSpec><setSpec>driver</setSpec></header><metadata><oai_dc:dc xmlns:oai_dc="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/" xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/  http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc.xsd"><dc:title xml:lang="en-US">Evidence Based Digoxin Therapeutic Monitoring - A Lower and Narrower Therapeutic Range</dc:title><dc:creator>Benlmouden, Amine</dc:creator><dc:creator>Billaud, Eliane</dc:creator><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Digoxin</dc:subject><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Drug monitoring</dc:subject><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Pharmacokinetic</dc:subject><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Pharmacodynamic</dc:subject><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Digitalics</dc:subject><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Heart fealure</dc:subject><dc:description xml:lang="en-US">Cardiac glycosides have been used for congestive heart failure and certain cardiac arrhythmias for more than 200 years. Despite the introduction of a variety of new classes of drugs for the management of heart failure, specifically angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors, b-adrenergic antagonists (bblockers), and the aldosterone antagonist spironolactone, digoxin continues to have an important role in long-term outpatient management. However, a narrow margin exists between therapeutic and toxic doses of digoxin, resulting in a high incidence of digoxin toxicity in clinical practice.
A wide variety of placebo-controlled clinical trials have unequivocally shown that treatment with digoxin can improve symptoms, quality of life, and exercise tolerance in patients with mild, moderate, or severe heart failure. The clinical relevance of digoxin therapeutic monitoring is also proved but the SDC (Serum Digoxin Conentrations) required for optimal clinical efﬁcacy and acceptable toxicity remains controversial. In the last years, international guidelines recommend 1.2 ng/mL as acceptable high level.
In this bibliographic synthesis, we aim to collect pertinent informations from MedLine database about exposure-effect relationship in order to assess the evidence level scientific of new digoxin therapeutic monitoring.</dc:description><dc:publisher xml:lang="en-US">Mediterranean Journals</dc:publisher><dc:date>2016-01-30</dc:date><dc:type>info:eu-repo/semantics/article</dc:type><dc:type>info:eu-repo/semantics/publishedVersion</dc:type><dc:format>application/pdf</dc:format><dc:identifier>https://www.mbmj.org/index.php/ijms/article/view/36</dc:identifier><dc:identifier>10.15342/ijms.v3i1.87</dc:identifier><dc:source xml:lang="en-US">Integrative Journal of Medical Sciences; Vol. 3 No. 1 (2016); 22-25</dc:source><dc:source>2658-8218</dc:source><dc:language>eng</dc:language><dc:relation>https://www.mbmj.org/index.php/ijms/article/view/36/361</dc:relation><dc:rights xml:lang="en-US">Copyright (c) 2016 Amine Benlmouden  and Eliane Billaud</dc:rights><dc:rights xml:lang="en-US">https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/</dc:rights></oai_dc:dc></metadata></record><record xmlns="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"><header><identifier>oai:ojs2.173.212.231.62:article/37</identifier><datestamp>2020-05-06T22:57:56Z</datestamp><setSpec>ijms:CR</setSpec><setSpec>driver</setSpec></header><metadata><oai_dc:dc xmlns:oai_dc="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/" xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/  http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc.xsd"><dc:title xml:lang="en-US">Intramuscular Benign Lipoma of the Biceps Brachii Muscle - A Case Report</dc:title><dc:creator>El Ibrahimi, Abdelhalim</dc:creator><dc:creator>Boussakri, Hassan</dc:creator><dc:creator>Elidrissi, Mohammed</dc:creator><dc:creator>Shimi, Mohammed</dc:creator><dc:creator>Elmrini, Abdelmajid</dc:creator><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Lipoma</dc:subject><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Intramuscular</dc:subject><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Biceps brachii</dc:subject><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Excision</dc:subject><dc:description xml:lang="en-US">Intramuscular lipoma is an uncommon mesenchymal neoplasm that characteristically infiltrates adjacent tissues and tends to recur after excision. Only a few publications referring to the upper extremities location have been reported. We report a case of an intramuscular lipoma of the biceps brachii muscle studied with MRI. Complete excision was performed without recurrence.</dc:description><dc:publisher xml:lang="en-US">Mediterranean Journals</dc:publisher><dc:date>2016-01-30</dc:date><dc:type>info:eu-repo/semantics/article</dc:type><dc:type>info:eu-repo/semantics/publishedVersion</dc:type><dc:format>application/pdf</dc:format><dc:identifier>https://www.mbmj.org/index.php/ijms/article/view/37</dc:identifier><dc:identifier>10.15342/ijms.v3i1.76</dc:identifier><dc:source xml:lang="en-US">Integrative Journal of Medical Sciences; Vol. 3 No. 1 (2016); 26-28</dc:source><dc:source>2658-8218</dc:source><dc:language>eng</dc:language><dc:relation>https://www.mbmj.org/index.php/ijms/article/view/37/360</dc:relation><dc:rights xml:lang="en-US">Copyright (c) 2016 Abdelhalim El Ibrahimi et al.</dc:rights><dc:rights xml:lang="en-US">https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/</dc:rights></oai_dc:dc></metadata></record><record xmlns="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"><header><identifier>oai:ojs2.173.212.231.62:article/38</identifier><datestamp>2020-05-06T22:58:35Z</datestamp><setSpec>ijms:CR</setSpec><setSpec>driver</setSpec></header><metadata><oai_dc:dc xmlns:oai_dc="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/" xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/  http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc.xsd"><dc:title xml:lang="en-US">A Chronic Psychogenic Vomiting Case of Dramatic Response to Escitalopram</dc:title><dc:creator>Ozturk, Onur</dc:creator><dc:creator>Selcuk, Mustafa Yasin</dc:creator><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Vomiting</dc:subject><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Pysicogenic</dc:subject><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Escitalopram</dc:subject><dc:description xml:lang="en-US">
This case report describes the treatment of an interesting patient with vomiting for years. The patient admitted to the family health center with chronic vomiting and weight loss. Her physical examination was unremarkable. The complaint of patient in who organic pathogen were excluded by biochemical and radiological examinations was evaluated psychologically; her complaints were ended following the initiation of escitalopram therapy unlike previous treatment. In this report, we represent a specific patient for the escitalopram treatment and thanks to this, it contributes a unique sample to the literature about escitalopram usage in the treatment of chronic vomiting.

Vol. 3 No. 1 (2016); 31</dc:source><dc:source>2658-8218</dc:source><dc:language>eng</dc:language><dc:relation>https://www.mbmj.org/index.php/ijms/article/view/39/363</dc:relation><dc:rights xml:lang="en-US">Copyright (c) 2016 Hanane Atarguine and Said Amal</dc:rights><dc:rights xml:lang="en-US">https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/</dc:rights></oai_dc:dc></metadata></record><record xmlns="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"><header><identifier>oai:ojs2.173.212.231.62:article/40</identifier><datestamp>2020-05-06T23:00:13Z</datestamp><setSpec>ijms:Rev</setSpec><setSpec>driver</setSpec></header><metadata><oai_dc:dc xmlns:oai_dc="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/" xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/  http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc.xsd"><dc:title xml:lang="en-US">Immediate Reactions To Monoclonal Antibodies In Clinical Hematology</dc:title><dc:creator>Kyriazi, Vasiliki</dc:creator><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Drug Allergy</dc:subject><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Hematology</dc:subject><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Hypersensitivity</dc:subject><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Infusion Reactions</dc:subject><dc:subject xml:lang="en-US">Monoclonal Antibodies</dc:subject><dc:description xml:lang="en-US">Monoclonal antibodies (MoAbs) have been widely used in clinical hematology. As foreign macro-molecules, they can cause infusional reactions during the administration or within 24 hours after the infusion, which encompass a spectrum of mechanisms. Although most of these reactions are non-allergic, are often indistinguishable from true allergic reactions mediated by IgE immunoglobulins. The diagnosis is often challenging and relies mainly on clinical criteria. They occur during the first doses, soon after the initiation of treatment. The symptoms are usually well controlled by the immediate drug discontinuation or reduction of the infusion rate. The management remains largely supportive, consisting of oxygen, intravenous fluids, bronchodilators, antihistamines and steroids. Most of MoAb protocols recommend premedication with steroids and antihistamines and gradually escalating infusion rates. Increased medical and nursing vigilance is required and resuscitative equipment should always be readily available. These events affect patients' quality of life, leading to treatment delay or discontinuation and series of tests. The decision to rechallenge the treatment depends on severity grading, clinical parameters and treatment goals. This article provides an update of MoAbs used in clinical hematology. It summarizes the pathophysiology, the diagnostic approach, the preventive measures and treatment of MoAb-related reactions.</dc:description><dc:publisher xml:lang="en-US">Mediterranean Journals</dc:publisher><dc:date>2016-01-30</dc:date><dc:type>info:eu-repo/semantics/article</dc:type><dc:type>info:eu-repo/semantics/publishedVersion</dc:type><dc:format>application/pdf</dc:format><dc:identifier>https://www.mbmj.org/index.php/ijms/article/view/40</dc:identifier><dc:identifier>10.15342/ijms.v3i2.102</dc:identifier><dc:source xml:lang="en-US">Integrative Journal of Medical Sciences; Vol. 3 No. 2 (2016); 32-39</dc:source><dc:source>2658-8218</dc:source><dc:language>eng</dc:language><dc:relation>https://www.mbmj.org/index.php/ijms/article/view/40/364</dc:relation><dc:rights xml:lang="en-US">Copyright
